abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Financial Sector Adjustment Credit in
            Bangladesh. The Project's objective was to support the
            Government of Bangladesh's (GOB) financial sector
            reform program and assist in financial restructuring of the
            nationalized commercial banks (NCBs). A host of factors,
            both subject to and not subject to government control,
            affected the achievement of project objectives. For
            instance, the GOB could not control the delay in securing a
            bank supervision expert, which adversely affected the
            ability of Bangladesh Bank (BB) to strengthen. However, the
            unwillingness of GOB and BB to reduce the deposit rate floor
            in line with falling inflation and to tighten or even
            enforce the existing lax loan classification and
            provisioning requirements affected the interest rate reform
            objectives. The NCB strengthening was adversely affected by
            GOB's failure to implement the politically difficult
            but necessary NCB management reforms including their
            compensation. The improvement in the debt recovery
            environment was affected by the delay in amending the
            Financial Loan Courts Act, 1990, to close the identified
            loopholes and expand the courts' jurisdiction. Finally,
            the initiation of the TA Project was delayed partly due to
            procedural delays in getting GOB clearances of individual consultants.
